body:
What do you mean "share notebooks"? Do you mean: allow users to be able to open someone else's notebook for running/editing? This might might be useful for collaborative editing, but currently that sounds very dangerous.

Currently, we require users to:
- download and upload notebooks to use them; or
- use a "Copy" function that copies it into their own Incoming directory

Here is a browse of shared notebooks in Public with copy/download links (for copy, user must be logged in):

http://jupyter.cs.brynmawr.edu/hub/dblank/public/

Here is a rendered view, with Download link:

http://jupyter.cs.brynmawr.edu/hub/dblank/public/CS110%20Intro%20to%20Computing/2015/Notes/Jan26.ipynb

A basic deployment of jupyterhub allows users to set unix permissions on
files to allow others use them:
- Open, read and run but not write
- Of full read, run, write access.

This just works out of the box and is the default simple way of sharing
content that we should support (even if many users don't enable it by
setting permissions on their files). I like the idea of the "Make a Copy"
of a read only notebook making that copy in a sort of incoming directory.
How did you implement that?

On Tue, Jan 27, 2015 at 8:42 AM, Doug Blank notifications@github.com
wrote:

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
@ellisonbg on Twitter and GitHub
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

Also, I love the idea of a public folder that knows how to nbconvert
notebooks to static. How are you doing that?

Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
@ellisonbg on Twitter and GitHub
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

Both are seat-of-my-pants hacks at the moment:

https://github.com/dsblank/jupyter.brynmawr/blob/master/jupyterhub/publichandler.py

This is embarrassing code... but the main take-away I think is the functionality. Briefly:
- when you "Publish", it copies your notebook into your Public folder (creates it if necessary), and sets proper permissions. This is an even larger hack [1] where the javascript sends the kernel Python code to execute, using callbacks to confirm and show URL of nbconvert-view of notebook (via PublicHandler)
- PublicHandler will list files in directory, show HTML, images, and render ipynb files (with header)
- Make a copy will do similar as Publish, but copies other's notebooks into an Incoming folder. 

Next, I'm working on:
- browsing others' "published" notebooks
- a "Submit" button for turning in homework

This is all prototype code to be suggestive to a developer of _what_ we want, but not _how_ it should be done.

[1] - https://bitbucket.org/ipre/calico/src/master/notebooks/nbextensions/calico-publish.js

@ellisonbg how do you propose implementing the default path, in terms of URLs? Would `/tree/` redirect to `/tree/default/path/`? That would make listing the root directory impossible. Would `/` redirect to `/default/path/`? Would the logo link go to default or home?

I think using the default path for the logo and `/` (not `/tree/`) links should work.
default_url was already present, and used for the `/` redirect. In #7608, I use the same URL for the logo link. I think that should cover this one.
@ellisonbg this got closed by Min's fix. Let us know if you think of anything more that should be done with this.

Sounds like it, but let me do a few tests before closing this...
